articles.title: In the parliamentary committee on the implementation of the recovery plan
articles.summary: The Ministry of Finance explained in a presentation on the implementation of the recovery and resilience plan to the competent parliamentary committee that the focus in the area of reform implementation is shifting to the execution of investments, where nearly 1400 projects are planned.
articles.content:
The Ministry of Finance explained in a presentation on the implementation of the recovery and resilience plan to the competent parliamentary committee that the focus in the area of reform implementation is shifting to the execution of investments, where nearly 1400 projects are planned.

Ljubljana – The parliamentary finance committee was informed on Tuesday about the implementation of the recovery and resilience plan. According to the state secretary at the Ministry of Finance Saša Jazbec, the government approved the proposal for the fourth amendment to the plan at the end of October and sent it to Brussels, with non-repayable funds remaining at 1.61 billion euros, while loans are reduced from 83 to 530 million euros.

Slovenia expects to receive the payment of the fourth request by the end of the year; after that, according to Jazbec, 72 percent of the total plan would be secured. Since 2026 will be an election year in Slovenia, she believes this could pose a challenge in implementing the reform part of the plan. To maximize the use of available funds, activities must be completed by June 30, 2026, with the deadline for exceptional cases expiring at the end of August, meaning the final request must be submitted to the commission by September 30, 2026.

Jazbec emphasized that so far, out of 36 reform measures, 22 have been implemented. Now, the investment part of the recovery plan is becoming more prominent. More than 1,360 projects are planned for implementation across Slovenia, and the state has already paid out 1.08 billion euros to end users. Several projects have already been completed. Jazbec mentioned those aimed at increasing the capacity of railway infrastructure, water supply and conservation, wastewater treatment and purification, as well as incentives in the fields of woodworking, digitalization, and robotization. (November 4)
articles.reasoning: The article reports on the significant progress and implementation of a national recovery and resilience plan involving over 1,360 projects with substantial funding, which will have broad positive impacts on infrastructure, environment, and digitalization in Slovenia. The focus on reform and investment execution with measurable funding and completed projects indicates meaningful real-world benefits for society. While the story is somewhat general, it provides enough detail on the scope and impact of the plan to be considered inspiring good news.
articles.personality_title: Slovenia advances with 1,400 projects in national recovery plan
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Slovenia is carrying out a recovery and resilience plan to rebuild and improve the country after recent challenges. This plan includes reforms and investments supported by European funds.

**What happened** – The Ministry of Finance told the parliamentary finance committee that the focus is shifting to investing in projects. Nearly 1,400 projects are planned across Slovenia, with over 1 billion euros already paid to support them. These projects include improving railways, water systems, and encouraging digital technologies and robotization.

**Impact** – So far, 22 out of 36 planned reforms have been completed, showing real progress. The many projects will improve important parts of daily life, like cleaner water and better transport. This work helps modernize the country and supports businesses, especially in technology and woodworking.

**What's next step** – Slovenia expects to receive another payment by the end of this year, securing 72% of the total plan funding. All activities must finish by June 2026, with a final report sent by September 2026. Since 2026 is an election year, completing reforms on time will be important.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Slovenia is making strong progress on a large recovery plan, investing in hundreds of projects to improve infrastructure, environment, and technology by 2026.
articles.personality_title_fr: La Slovénie avance avec 1 400 projets dans son plan de relance national
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La Slovénie met en œuvre un plan de relance et de résilience pour reconstruire et améliorer le pays après des difficultés récentes. Ce plan comprend des réformes et des investissements soutenus par des fonds européens.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le ministère des Finances a informé la commission parlementaire des finances que l’accent est désormais mis sur les investissements. Près de 1 400 projets sont prévus à travers la Slovénie, avec plus d’un milliard d’euros déjà versés pour les soutenir. Ces projets incluent l’amélioration des chemins de fer, des systèmes d’eau et la promotion des technologies numériques et de la robotisation.

**Impact** – Jusqu’à présent, 22 des 36 réformes prévues ont été réalisées, montrant un réel progrès. Les nombreux projets amélioreront des aspects importants de la vie quotidienne, comme une eau plus propre et un meilleur transport. Ce travail aide à moderniser le pays et soutient les entreprises, notamment dans la technologie et la menuiserie.

**Prochaine étape** – La Slovénie s’attend à recevoir un nouveau versement d’ici la fin de l’année, assurant 72 % du financement total du plan. Toutes les activités doivent être terminées d’ici juin 2026, avec un rapport final envoyé avant septembre 2026. Comme 2026 est une année électorale, il sera important de finir les réformes à temps.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – La Slovénie progresse fortement dans un vaste plan de relance, investissant dans des centaines de projets pour améliorer les infrastructures, l’environnement et la technologie d’ici 2026.
articles.personality_title_es: Eslovenia avanza con 1.400 proyectos en su plan nacional de recuperación
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Eslovenia está llevando a cabo un plan de recuperación y resiliencia para reconstruir y mejorar el país tras desafíos recientes. Este plan incluye reformas e inversiones apoyadas por fondos europeos.

**Qué pasó** – El Ministerio de Finanzas informó al comité parlamentario de finanzas que el enfoque se está trasladando a la inversión en proyectos. Se planean cerca de 1.400 proyectos en toda Eslovenia, con más de 1.000 millones de euros ya pagados para apoyarlos. Estos proyectos incluyen mejorar ferrocarriles, sistemas de agua y fomentar tecnologías digitales y robotización.

**Impacto** – Hasta ahora, 22 de las 36 reformas planificadas se han completado, mostrando un progreso real. Los muchos proyectos mejorarán partes importantes de la vida diaria, como agua más limpia y mejor transporte. Este trabajo ayuda a modernizar el país y apoya a las empresas, especialmente en tecnología y carpintería.

**Próximo paso** – Eslovenia espera recibir otro pago para fin de año, asegurando el 72% del financiamiento total del plan. Todas las actividades deben completarse antes de junio de 2026, con un informe final enviado para septiembre de 2026. Dado que 2026 es año electoral, completar las reformas a tiempo será clave.

**Resumen en una frase** – Eslovenia avanza firmemente en un gran plan de recuperación, invirtiendo en cientos de proyectos para mejorar infraestructura, medio ambiente y tecnología para 2026.
